I'll let me get this little higher hey
so I am Tom Brown from open AI and today
we're gonna learn in five minutes Coop's
for noobs so first a quick word on noobs
noobs are just people who are learning a
product for the first time this talk is
not directed at noobs so if you're
hoping to learn about coop cuddle get
pods you will not learn about that today
instead I'm gonna talk about some
product building stuff and how you can
make tools that noobs actually love and
continue to use until they no longer are
groups so first a quick word about open
a I open AI is a non-profit research
company that is trying to build safe AI
and so we're about like eighty percent
researchers everyone at the company is
technical it's about 60 people ish now
and so most of the work that we do is
running experiments so basically each
thing that we deploy is this beautiful
and unique snowflake so everybody has to
learn how to use Kubb and then we have a
couple other things like we have since
we're very bursty we have an ec2
autoscaler and a bunch of other goodies
that um Viki and Jonas my colleagues are
gonna talk about in their keynote
tomorrow at 10:00 so my first couple
weeks at open AI Viki and Jonas had
basically built out our coop cluster and
I had never used it before so my
experience was kind of like reading
through the docs or like when I got
stuck seeing whatever magic command it
was that they use to unblock themselves
and I think originally when I submitted
this I was going to talk about all the
ways that the coop Doc's were just
failing their users but ever the last
like two months they've actually become
very good so good work coop people I'm
gonna cut that entire section from this
talk
so what I was doing then during that
time was noticing places where I got
stuck and I would just write it in a doc
and so the first thing if you want to
make a product that's great for users
and for noobs is to write Doc's for
yourself I called this doc Kubb for
noobs and basically then whenever
someone else went through - they would
add stuff to that doc and what's nice
about that is that it's literally no
effort you are already figuring out the
stuff you just like dump it in a doc and
what you end up with then is actually a
good technical documentation for exactly
the tasks that people within your org
and then the other type of way yeah the
other type of Doc's that you will build
is many of you are building stuff on top
of coup or building other products
you'll want to write Doc's for your
users and this is a little bit more
difficult because you have the curse of
knowledge so the tried-and-true trick
for this is basically user interviews so
you write Doc's as best as you can and
then you go and physically sit with a
user and see what it is that they like
where it is that they get stuck and
often it will be in like surprising ways
so the classic things that you'll want
to go and ask them are like what are
they trying to do where is it that
they're confused what are like the
questions that they have that aren't
immediately answered and you can also
look at like where they go and start
trying to look for documentation as a
hint that your product isn't usable yet
so basically write your Doc's watch a
user and then you just repeat that and
what we try to do at open AI is to make
sure that any product that we build
isn't finished until any new user can
come and figure out how to do the key
workflows for it with just ten minutes
of reading the dots and basically the
practice for that is just watch a noob
do it then watch another noob and if you
follow these like simple things you'll
end up building
tools the noobs really will love thank
you I'm Tom Brown if you want to learn
more about building different products
for particular research feel free to
email me Tom at opening Thanks
